column4: TOOLTIP
The levy limit restricts the real and personal property taxes imposed by a city or town the previous fiscal year
Massachusetts limits the growth of the general property levy to 2 1/2 percent each year (exclusive of New Growth, overrides or exclusions)
Additional tax revenue generated by new construction, renovations and other increases in the property tax base during a calendar year.
An override is a vote by a community at an election to permanently increase the levy limt.
An override is a vote by a community at an election to permanently increase the levy limt. June 7, 2011 voters passed a $6.5 million override

An action taken by a community through a referendum vote to raise the funds necessary to pay debt service costs for a particular project from the property tax levy, but outside the limits under Proposition 2 1/2. The amount is added to the levy limit for the life of the debt only and may increase the levy above the levy ceiling.

An action taken by a community through a referendum vote to raise the funds necessary to pay debt service costs for a particular project from the property tax levy, but outside the limits under Proposition 2 1/2. The amount is added to the levy limit for the life of the debt only and may increase the levy above the levy ceiling.

Chapter 70 refers to the school fuding formula created under the Education Reform Act of 1993 by which State Aid is distributed through the Cherry Sheet to help establish educational equity among municipal and regional school districts
Money appropriated from the balance of the State Lottery Fund and additional aid to municipalities
State aid to municipalities from the State Lotery Fund and other funds - combined with Unrestricted General Government Aid starting FY2010

column3: Exemptions: Vets, Blind Persons & Surviving Spouses
column4: State reimbursement of the costs of providing services for veterans, blind persons and surviving spouses
State reimbursement for elderly services
Revenue derived from collection of motor vehicle excise taxes
Revenue derived from the meals tax and hotel tax.

Payments In Lieu of Taxes - Certain organizations, such as schools and non-profit institutions, are exempt from paying some taxes such as property taxes. PILOTs are voluntary payments made to the Town by such groups in recognition that they use Town services but are not obligated to pay certain taxes.
Fees include charges for ambulance fees, parking violations, Town Clerk fees, etc.

The Town derives income from the renting of several Town-owned properties including the Gibbs and Parmenter schools, the Mt. Gilboa house, the former Dallin Library, and former Department buildings at Ryder Street.
Revenue collected for the issuance of licenses and permits to restaurants, bars, parking, marriage, etc.
In accordance with M.G.L. Ch. 40 S. 5B, the Town may appropriate in any year an amount not exceeding, in the aggregate, 10% of the amount raised in the preceding fiscal year's tax levy.

This Fund was created as a result of the 2005 Proposition 2 1/2 override. The Town makes annual appropriations to the fund until the time in which it is necessary to make withdrawals for the purposes of balancing the general fund budget.
A revenue source that results from the calculation, as of July 1, of a community's remaining, unrestricted funds from operations of the previous fiscal year, based on the balance sheet as of June 30.
In accordance with M.G.L. Ch. 40 S. 13, the Town established this fund for the purposes of offsetting the costs associated with significant property loss.
The Town of Arlington participated in a regional solid waste consortium, and upon leaving the consortium in September 2005, the Town was entitled to revenue derived from the regional agreement.
